question.title: Why the package org.junit does not exist with maven but runs fine in Eclipse?
question.body:
I have a project that runs the tests fine in Eclipse. If I run mvn verify after Eclipse compiled the project, at first sight it seems to run every test class fine, just runs 0 tests in each of them.

mvn clean verify results in the following error:

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-compiler-plugin:3.1:testCompile (default-testCompile) on project jcivitas: Compilation failure: Compilation failure: 
[ERROR] /home/mag/project/civitas-0.7.1/jcivitas/src/test/java/civitas/common/util/ReadSimpleIntTagTest.java:[3,24] package org.junit does not exist
[ERROR] /home/mag/project/civitas-0.7.1/jcivitas/src/test/java/civitas/common/util/ReadSimpleIntTagTest.java:[3,1] static import only from classes and interfaces

I checked everything I have found on Stack Overflow so far. My tests are in the test directory, I include junit 5 in the pom, I use org.junit.jupiter.api imports, removed my ~/.m2 directory. I synchronized with Maven in Eclipse. It was working until a point (I already have 99 tests written), but I added some stuff to my pom.xml, and it went downhill. (Those are deleted very early in the struggle.) I have already tried all dependency combinations for JUnit 5 I found on the net, including those in the JUnit 5 documentation.

A quirk of the project is that I need to use Java 8. The JDK 8 build on the system is Temurin (build 1.8.0_432-b06).

Here is my current pom.xml:

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

  <groupId>com.kodekonveyor</groupId>
  <artifactId>jcivitas</artifactId>
  <version>0.0.1-SNAPSHOT</version>
  <packaging>jar</packaging>

  <name>jcivitas</name>

  <properties>
     <maven.compiler.source>1.8</maven.compiler.source>
     <maven.compiler.target>1.8</maven.compiler.target>
    <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
  </properties>
  <dependencies>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
        <version>5.13.0-M3</version>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-jupiter</artifactId>
        <version>5.13.0-M3</version>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.mockito</groupId>
        <artifactId>mockito-core</artifactId>
        <version>4.0.0</version>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
  </dependencies>
</project>

The beginning of the java source mentioned in the error:

package civitas.common.util;

import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertEquals;
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertThrows;

import java.io.IOException;

import org.junit.jupiter.api.DisplayName;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

import civitas.common.Util;

public class ReadSimpleTagTest extends UtilTestBase {

answers.body:
After I have deleted Junit from the eclipse java build path it became apparent that I use old org.junit imports in some other java files. After fixing them the project compiles both in eclipse and maven.

Maven still found all the test classes but no tests in them. The fix for that was to include junit-jupiter-engine and junit-platform-launcher dependencies and maven-surefire-plugin.

question_comments.body: Here is a full example... github.com/khmarbaise/youtube-videos/tree/main/episode-1

Thank you for the hints. It is the same with 5.12.2. Actually the package is only in test, and the class is only in main. Those are the tests for the class. It is a sort of refactoring project, and after the refactor there will not be such a class.

I think it's not related to your problem, but as a point of interoperability: you seem to have a package civitas.common.util, and a class civitas.common.Util, and on OSes with case-insensitive filesystems (Windows, macOS), that could lead to confusion, so you should avoid such duplicate naming.
Have you tried with a released version of JUnit (e.g. 5.12.2) instead of a development milestone (5.13.0-M3)?

79616236.body: You have to define the maven-surefire-plugin  best most recent version... also other plugins should be defined within your build....
